sentences.original: kêtahtawê âsa mîna êh-ây-ihkihk, mîna kotak iyahciyiniw k-âsitêyimât kotakah nâpêwah.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê âsay mîna ê-âh-ihkihk mîna kotak ayahciyiniw kâ-âsitêyimât kotaka nâpêwa
sentences.english: Another thing which used to happen, was when some Blackfoot became suspicious about another man.
“You are consorting with that young man,” he would tell her.
“Oh dear, no!”
“Yes, you are, just the same!
Tomorrow you will go to the great sand-hill.”

sentences.original: êkwah êh-wâpahk, kâ-wawêyît, kâ-miywâsikih kitayôwinisah postiskah.
sentences.english: Then, the next morning, when he had made ready, “Put on your best clothes.”
Accordingly she dressed up.

sentences.original: wayawîtimihk êkwah kitâpam iskwêyâc kâ-manitôwit pîsim, itêw.
sentences.english: “Go outside now and for the last time look upon the holy sun.”
Then the woman went outside.
She looked upon the sun; then she came in.

sentences.original: tânimâh wâh-otinaman ? itêw owîkimâkanah; ta-nipiyan, awêkâh ta-kîskikotêyan ?
sentences.english: “Which will you take?” he asked his wife; “To die, or that I cut off your nose?”
Then the woman answered him, “Cut off my nose.”
He cut off her nose.

sentences.original: âyakô mina kayâs ayahciyiniwak kâ-kâhkwêyihtahkik, wîwiwâwah êkosi ê-kîh-tôtawâcik, mayôwês wiyasôwêwin ihtakohk, pikw îsi kâ-kîh-tôtawâcik wîwiwâwa.
sentences.text: êwako mîna kayâs ayahciyiniwak kâ-kâhkwêyihtahkik wîwiwâwa êkosi ê-kî-tôtawâcik maywês wiyasôwêwin ihtakohk piko isi kâ-kî-tôtawâcik wîwiwâwa
sentences.english: This is another example of how the Blackfoot of old, when they were jealous, treated their wives, before there was law, when they did what they pleased to their wives.

sentences.original: mâk êkwah anohc nama takon êyakw ânima;
sentences.text: mâka êkwa anohc nama takon êwako anima
sentences.english: But now this no longer happens;
now the women live in peace.
Then they were tormented; but now they are delivered from it.

sentences.original: êkwah minah ê-kîh-paskoswâcik, êyôkonik nêhiyawak, ê-kîsi-nôtiniskwêwêcik, êkwah nama wîhkâc maninâk ohci nipahêwak, pikôh êh-kîs-kîskahwâcik wîwiwâwa, êyakonik nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: êkwa mîna ê-kî-paskoswâcik êwakonik nêhiyawak ê-kîsi-nôtiniskwêwêcik êkwa nama wîhkâc mâninâk ohci nipahêwak piko ê-kîsi-kîskahwâcik wîwiwâwa êyakonik nêhiyawak
sentences.english: These Cree, too, mutilated their wives when they were angry at them, but they never went as far as killing them; they only cut them up, did these Cree.

sentences.original: êyakonik nêhiyawak kâ-kîh-tôtahkik; mâk êkwa nama-kîkwâwiyiw.
sentences.text: êyakonik nêhiyawak kâ-kî-tôtahkik mâka êkwa nama-kîkwayiyiw
sentences.english: That was what these Cree did, but now it has ceased.

sentences.original: êyakw ânimah miywêyihtamwak kahkiyaw êh-pônipayiyik iskwêwak, mitonih êh-wânaskêcik.
sentences.text: êwako anima miywêyihtamwak kahkiyaw ê-pônipayiyik iskwêwak mitoni ê-wânaskêcik
sentences.english: The women are glad that it has stopped, for they are delivered from great suffering.
